p: Table 1 summarizes the baseline characteristics of HIV-1-positive women diagnosed in Israel in the years 2010–2012, 2013–2015 and 2016–2018. Median age at diagnosis was 38. Main route of HIV transmission (82.4%, n = 629) was sexual contact; only 10.9% ( n = 83) were injecting drug users (IDUs). Most women were immigrants: 41.2% ( n = 314) were born in the FSU, 32.2% ( n = 246) in SSA and only 11.4% ( n = 87) were born in Israel. While the total number of women identified remained stable over the study period, a significant yearly decline in the proportion of SSA immigrants versus a constant increase in women originating from the FSU was observed ( p < 0.001). Similarly, while the overall prevalence of subtype C (41.8%, 141/337) and A (38.6%, 130/337) diagnosis was similar, the later years of the study were associated with a decline in the number of subtype C carriers and an increase in the number of subtype A carriers.
